Award.AwardTitle: An Analysis of Innovation and Performance in U.S. Biofuel Firms: Implications for the Biofuel Technological Innovation System

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project focuses on an analysis of the evolution of the biofuel technological innovation system within the United States, with emphasis on both first- and second-generation biofuels. The biofuel industry, characterized by new and incremental process innovation, differs from other manufacturing because it is resource-based, it is localized, it is driven by policy and alliances, and it has high levels of uncertainty in the incubation and commercialization of new feedstock-based production. These conditions facilitate risk-balancing organizational networks that result in the formation of a geographically embedded technological innovation system. The development of second-generation biofuels using cellulosic technologies has introduced new process-development possibilities, which cannot be accomplished within the boundaries of a single firm or a region. This project will examine firm-level adjustments as biofuel production expands from kernel-based to second-generation (cellulosic) technologies. The investigators will analyze firm performance and the role of the producer within the U.S. biomass-based biofuel technological innovation system. They will focus on analysis of answers to two specific sets of questions: (1) What internal and external factors determine innovation and business performance in biofuel firms, and to what extent do biofuel firms depend on local policy and partners to improve performance? (2) How do adjustments in firm-level processes affect system-wide functions, and how do firms shape and reshape the overall environment of biofuel innovation and production? Data will be gathered from surveys and archived documents, with both quantitative and qualitative methods used to understand factors affecting the evolution of this industry.

The project will advance basic understanding of localized renewable energy production. It will develop a conceptual and analytical framework transferable to other energy industries, industries with non-assembled products, or any emerging geographically embedded technological innovation system. It will advance studies of innovation and firm performance, which occupy a central place in economic geography. While most studies have focused focus on product innovation and manufacturing, this project will focus on a resource-based industry and process innovation. Resource industries have critical and distinct roles to play in the debate over economy and environment. Process-oriented technological change is vital to firm performance and industrial advancement. The project will contribute toward economic geography theorizing by moving beyond industrial demography and case studies through its analysis of many firms and the effect of their actions on the larger industry. The project also will have policy implications, which will emerge from the analysis of firm adjustments to changes in their external environment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research was motivated by an interest in understanding the characteristics of one of the major industrial sectors in renewable energy: biofuel (e.g., corn-based ethanol).  In the United States, the main input for biofuel production is corn.  Other feedstocks (e.g., switchgrass) have been experimented with but corn continues to be the main input.  The time period under consideration is before and after the 2008 economic downturn.  The research also led to a broader interest in understanding investments (as well as investment potential) in renewables in the United States and transition potential to renewables (e.g., solar). Related research emerged from a basic interest in energy transition?barriers and facilitators of energy transition (e.g., solar, liquefied petroleum gas) in developing countries.  First, the outcomes from the biofuel/ethanol research include an understanding of the patterns (e.g., science, ownership, location) of patent classes considered to be connected to the biofuel industry in 1973-1977, 1993-1997, and 2008-2012. The producers of biofuels are not necessarily the owners of patents?while the owners are seed companies, enzyme producers, universities, and government laboratories, the producers are mainly agri-processing companies with a few dedicated ethanol companies, mostly located in the Midwest.  The patent class evolution notes the growing importance of molecular biology similar to what is observed in the development of biotechnology for agricultural purposes (e.g., seeds, enzymes).

Second, the study examined the location and survival (a proxy for performance) of ethanol refineries. Refinery population includes a variety of companies and the geographic distribution is uneven in the Midwest. Small cooperatives involving farmers also operate refineries, often small (<65 million gallons per year) but incumbent agri-processors and dedicated ethanol producers dominate.  While biofuel production was jumpstarted with policy incentives prior to 2008, the survival of the producers after 2008 depended on many factors such as deep knowledge of the industry.  Several new entrants experimenting with new feedstocks (e.g., switchgrass) or trying to capitalize using various incentives did not survive. Third, among those refineries surveyed during the study, input from outside sources has been very important for adjusting their internal strategies in response to external pressures.  For example, a slightly larger number of small refineries (<65 million gallon per year), compared to those producing greater than 65 mgy, indicated that higher than one percent of their sales is dedicated to R&D.  Networks to obtain technical knowledge for diversification into producing better distillers grains (e.g., by product development) are important combined with a close connection with machinery producers (e.g., bolt-on technology) to improve efficiency. Like other small-and medium-sized companies, Midwestern refineries place critical importance on technical knowledge gained from suppliers (e.g., enzymes) and distributors (e.g., blending needs) as well as on partnering strategies to reduce cost (e.g., human resources, marketing).

Next, like many other emerging industry, finances are an important need for renewable energy. The comparative analysis of investments in biofuels with other renewables (solar and wind) focused on understanding patterns of venture capital investment. California is used as a case study given that it is one of the leading states in terms of policy development toward renewables and the presence of venture capital firms.  The origin-destination of venture capital investments in renewables, especially solar and biofuels, is centered on San Francisco and San Jose indicating a close connection to innovation potential (e.g., photovoltaic, biotechnology). A detailed analysis of the recipients of investment flows to and from San Francisco, as well as the reach of San Francisco based investors elsewhere is conducted to show the local and non-local networks of a leading hub of renewable energy innovation. Venture capital investment connections in renewables among other California metropolitan areas are not as extensive.  These patterns illustrate the geographies of innovation in renewables.

Finally, related projects focused on the potential for energy transition (e.g., solar) and transition to either solar or cleaner fuels. This line of research is motivated by an interest in understanding the barriers/facilitators for different categories of renewables: biofuels for transportation (e.g., the role of policy, innovation, adjustments to refinery operations), solar for electrification (e.g., rooftop and community potentials), and cleaner fuels for the reduction of energy poverty as well as pollution (e.g., solar for electrification coupled with liquefied petroleum gas or LPG for cooking).  In the United States, the potential for solar (rooftop and community solar) is analyzed using remotely sensed data and socio-economic variables. The adoption of solar in a poor country (e.g., Bangladesh) shows the importance of household decision-making that is not always based on economic barriers.  The transition to better fuels in low and middle income countries (e.g., Peru, Nepal) is affected by policy, regional location, and various household-level factors.  In all of the above cases, policy adjustments are needed at the local level to overcome implementation barriers. Stakeholders face numerous risks that often show geographic variation.
